pd_0_com_1text: Get out of my kitchen-a. I've told you so many times tat you cano't ave any of tis cooking-a. Dese arrre forrr de Lorrrd's gooests-a.
pd_0_com_2text: I alrrready gave you de rrremains of de meal yestoiday. If you walk in ere so frrreely doorrring de day, I wil-l be firrred because of you.
pd_1_com_0text: You must be confusing me with someone else. I am ShAIRlock Holmes.
pd_2_com_0text: I don't know any ShAIRRRlock olmes-a.
pd_2_com_8text: I rrread ShAIRRRlock olmes in de giorrrnale.
pd_2_com_9text: Oh-a, you'rrre ere as a gooest-a?
pd_2_com_10text: ow cano de oomble Palloncino d'aria elp you?
pd_3_com_0text: Palloncino, you can help me by answering some questions about the lord and the guests here.
pd_4_com_0text: The thing with the lord. ow toirrrible!

pd_8_com_1text: Palloncino, could you answer some questions about the lord and the guests?
pd_10_com_1text: She's on angelo who fel-l frrrom de sky to save me.

pd_10_com_5text: Ma il mio mistero è chiuso in me,
pd_10_com_7text: No, no. Dilegua, o notte! Tramontate, stelle!
pd_11_com_0text: De generale is-a fool-l of ot airrr-a!
pd_11_com_1text: e fought in de warrr molti anni fa and since den e as done niente.
pd_11_com_2text: Al-l e does is-a talk about de warrr and insoolt my cooking-a.
pd_11_com_3text: I stoodied cooking in de best airrr cooking schools in nel mondo.
pd_11_com_4text: Dese Bal-loonians ave no taste forrr cucina raffinata.
pd_12_com_0text: [The General doesn't seem to have been particularly successful since the war.]
pd_12_com_1text: Palloncino, how can you say that? I think your food is excellent. It's been a long time since I had the chance to eat something so delicious.
pd_13_com_1text: You arrre a bal-loon of de worrrld-a.
pd_13_com_2text: I'm-a afrrraid ere arrre voiy few who tink so.
pd_13_com_3text: In rrreality, only Signor ShAIRRRlock olmes and de bel-la don-na ot-airrr bal-loon-a.
pd_14_com_0text: What else can you tell me about the General?
pd_15_com_0text: Sì, I saw today ow de generale ad come out of de Lorrrd's stoody, e looked voiy angrrry and irrr-rrritated-a.
pd_15_com_1text: Boot I ad seen de lorrrd in de dining rrroom with is gooests joost beforrre.
pd_15_com_2text: What was de generale doing dere?
pd_15_com_3text: It's-a not my job to arrrgooe with de gooests-a, so I didn't ask im-a.
pd_15_com_4text: I'm-a soorrre dere's a explanation logica.
pd_15_com_5text: I wanted to rrreporrrt tis to de lorrrd-a, boot oonforrrtoonately tat is-a no longoi pos-sible.
pd_16_com_0text: [The general had secretly sneaked into the lord's study?]
pd_18_com_1text: Signor olmes is-a asking about Palloncino?
pd_18_com_3text: Palloncino cano tel-l you about Palloncino.
pd_18_com_4text: I was borrrn in de distant land of Airrrland in a smal-l vil-lage.
pd_18_com_5text: Mia madre was a local and mio padre a Baloonioi-a.
pd_18_com_6text: Boot mia madre rrraised me alone, because mio padre was always at worrrk in Baloonia.
pd_18_com_7text: At school I met a coote lit-tle bal-loon-a, my firrrst love. Boot a few yearrrs latoi er family marrr-rrried er to ano eldoily rrrich noblemano-a.
pd_18_com_8text: Tat was de firrrst time lit-tle Palloncino's lit-tle earrrt was brrroken-a.
pd_18_com_9text: I was a norrrmal kid den-a, joost prrranks in de ead and nevoi voiy good at school-a. OOntil one day Maestro Aerostato discovoied my talent forrr de cooking in a school cooking competition-a.
pd_18_com_10text: e said to me, "Palloncino, yourrr food is-a de only ting ere I'd esitate on beforrre trrrowing it in de trrrash-a."
pd_18_com_11text: At firrrst I was ap-prrrenticing in is kitchen and when e couldn't teach me anything anymorrre e paid forrr my stoodies in de best cooking schools in del mondo.
pd_18_com_12text: I cano tel-l you so many storrries frrrom tat time.
pd_19_com_0text: And I'll be happy to hear them all some other time. But tell me now rather how you ended up here.
pd_20_com_1text: It al-l begano when mia madre sood-denly became voiy il-l-a.
pd_20_com_2text: She couldn't worrrk anymorrre and so I drrrop-ped out of my trrraining and rrretoorrrned ome to elp er-a.
pd_20_com_3text: When my father found out about tis-a, e brrrought oos both to Bal-loonia.
pd_20_com_4text: We woie doing bet-toi dere forrr a while, boot when mia madre did not rrrecovoi forrr a long time, e left oos forrr another donna.
pd_20_com_5text: And so I ended oop al-l alone with mia sick mamma in a forrreign countrrry.
pd_20_com_6text: I trrried to find a job as a cook to earrrn some money, boot since I didn't speak de langooage prrropoily and didn't ave a completed trrraining-a, nobody wanted to irrre poorrr Palloncino.
pd_21_com_0text: Why didn't you ask Maestro Aerostato for help?
pd_22_com_0text: Oh-a, Signor olmes-a, de Maestro believes I've become a famous celebrrrity chef in Airmerica.
pd_22_com_1text: I don't ave de earrrt to tel-l im de trrrooth-a.
pd_23_com_0text: Then how did you end up in Lord Zeppelin's house?
pd_24_com_1text: In orrrdoi to earrrn some money at al-l-a, I opened a smal-l strrreet stal-l and sold my trrraditional omemade soup-a.
pd_24_com_2text: I made joost enough to make ends meet-a.
pd_24_com_3text: Boot one day a marrrvelous angel came to save me. De young lady ot airrr bal-loon came by with de Lorrrd Zep-pelin and she insisted tat dey taste my cooking-a.
pd_24_com_4text: Dey liked it so mooch dey irrred me as a cook-a, and ere I am-a.
pd_24_com_5text: I rrrememboi exactly what Lorrrd Zep-pelin said to me back den: "Is it ydrrrogen-frrree? Because of my ydrrrogen intoloiance, I cano only eat elioom food-a."
pd_24_com_6text: Of courrrse! I only oose de best ingrrredients forrr my dishes-a. It's-a a question of cook onorrr-a!
pd_25_com_0text: [That means the cook definitely knew about Lord Zeppelin's condition.]
pd_25_com_1text: Thank you very much for this detailed story.
pd_26_com_0text: You arrre always welcome ere, Signor olmes-a. Arrivederci.
pd_27_com_0text: Palloncino, can you tell me again the story of how the lord hired you as a cook?
pd_28_com_3text: I don't have any more questions.
pd_29_com_0text: "Signora hot air balloon, I love you and cannot bear to live another day without you."
pd_29_com_1text: Palloncino, you know who wrote this letter, don't you?
pd_29_com_2text: Maybe you should just tell me what this is all about.
pd_30_com_1text: I have the love letter in one hand and the recipe for the soup in the other.
pd_30_com_2text: When I compare the writing, your characteristic sweeping letters, there is no more doubt that you are the author of the letter.
pd_31_com_0text: It wasn't me. It wasn't me. I cano't-a, she was de don-na of my bos-s-a.
pd_31_com_1text: Tat would be completely oonprrrofes-sional-a. I moost not love er-a.
pd_32_com_0text: She WAS the boss's wife, Palloncino.
pd_32_com_1text: You know that's not very well received in court. Not at all. That's a strong motive for murder.
pd_32_com_2text: If you believe the church of Balloonia, the oldest of them all.
pd_32_com_3text: The evidence is enough to convince the judges and you know what the punishment for murder in Balloonia is, right?
pd_33_com_0text: Signor ShAIRRRlock olmes-a, I beg you. Believe me, I cano-not tel-l you any morrre!!!
pd_34_com_1text: [But he must have a strong reason not to tell me.]
pd_34_com_2text: [If I had proof that he wrote the love letter, I could confront him with it. But how can I prove it?]
pd_34_com_4text: Palloncino, I decided to help you.

pd_35_com_3text: ow cano I evoi pay you back-a?

pd_38_com_0text: The recipe for your traditional homemade soup. You told me about it when you told me about your past, remember?
pd_39_com_0text: Palloncino, you never told me how the story with your mother ended.
pd_40_com_0text: Ahah! Tat's it-a? You arrre a voiy modest bal-loon-a, Signor olmes-a.
pd_40_com_1text: Certo! I'l-l wrrrite de rrrecipe down forrr you rrright away.

pd_42_com_0text: Not a good ending-a, Signor olmes-a.

pd_52_com_1text: Do you believe tat now as she is-a oonmarrr-rrried again-a, dere is-a a chance tat my love wil-l be rrretoorrrned-a?
pd_53_com_0text: Anything is possible, Palloncino. But don't push her too hard, she just lost her husband.
pd_54_com_0text: Grazie forrr yourrr advice, Signor olmes-a. You arrre so wise.
pd_55_com_0text: You're welcome. See you soon, I still have something to check.
pd_57_com_0text: So I asked you what you knew about the lady, and you did that.
pd_57_com_2text: This was a complete breath of fresh air.
pd_57_com_3text: I thought you were absolutely fantastic.
pd_59_com_0text: Grazie. Signor Palloncino, you have served me brilliantly.
pd_60_com_0text: [Assuming the general found the medication while searching the Lord's study, he would then also have had access to the murder weapon.]

pd_64_com_0text: [All I have to do is prove that he had the means to convict him.]
